A 22-year-old man comes to the clinic complaining of a 6-week history of intermittent abdominal pain. The patient states the pain is located mainly in the right upper quadrant and typically occurs after meals. The patient denies any past medical history. He states his father had his spleen removed at a young age but is unsure of the details. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows mucosal pallor and scleral icterus. There is no pain on palpation of the abdomen. The spleen tip is palpable. Laboratory results are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?  

Laboratory value  Result (U.S. conventional units) Results (SI units) 
 Hematologic   
 Leukocyte count   6,000/mm3  6 *10^9/L 
 Platelet count  175,000/mm3   175 *10^9/L 
 Hemoglobin  10.1 g/dL  101 g/L 
 Mean corpuscular volume (MCV)   84  μm3  84 fL 
 Mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC)  40 g/dL  400 g/L 
 Red cell distribution width (RDW)  15%  - 
 Reticulocyte count   8.1%  -

choices.text: Intermittent common bile duct obstruction with brown pigment gallstones
Intermittent gallbladder obstruction with black pigment gallstones
Spasm of the biliary tracts secondary to cholesterol stone obstruction

questions.solution:
This young adult, who presents with complaints of postprandial right upper quadrant (RUQ) pain and laboratory results showing anemia and elevated mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC), likely has black pigment gallstone formation secondary to hereditary spherocytosis (HS).  

Black pigment gallstones form when the bile contains a high concentration of unconjugated bilirubin in the bilirubin tree, such as in patients with chronic extravascular red cell hemolysis. This can be seen in patients with sickle cell disease or hereditary spherocytosis. Brown pigment stones, on the other hand, can precipitate when the biliary tract is infected by certain microbes (e.g., E. coli, Clonorchis sinensis) that produce β-glucuronidase, an enzyme that unconjugates previously conjugated bilirubin. Unconjugated bilirubin is water insoluble and combines with calcium to form brown pigment stones.  

However, the most common gallstones are cholesterol stones. Bile formation is the only significant pathway for the body to eliminate excess cholesterol, either as free cholesterol or as bile salts. Cholesterol becomes water-soluble when combined with bile salts; therefore, when cholesterol concentrations exceed the solubility capacity of bile salts (supersaturation), cholesterol stones can form. Conditions that increase cholesterol synthesis (e.g. obesity) or decrease bile salt formation (e.g., malabsorptive conditions, medications such as fibrates) predispose individuals to forming gallstones. Additionally, hypomotility of the gallbladder results in bile stasis, which also promotes gallstone formation (e.g., pregnant women, patients on total parenteral nutrition). This patient did not have risk factors for cholesterol stones. Instead, his physical exam and laboratory values suggested a risk for pigment stones.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Acalculous inflammation of the gallbladder :
Incorrect: Acalculous cholecystitis is an acute inflammatory disorder of the gallbladder that is most commonly seen in conditions that cause biliary stasis, such as in critically ill patients (e.g., multiorgan failure, post-surgery, trauma) or those on prolonged total parenteral nutrition (TPN). Patients typically present with fever and persistent right upper quadrant pain, neither of which are seen in this patient.  
❌ Intermittent common bile duct obstruction with brown pigment gallstones :
Incorrect: Brown pigment stones are associated with bacterial (e.g. E. coli) or parasitic (e.g. liver fluke) infections of the biliary system. Brown pigment stones are prevalent in Asian countries but are rarely seen in patients in the United States. Additionally, this patient’s underlying condition predisposes him to a different type of stone composition.
✅ Intermittent gallbladder obstruction with black pigment gallstones:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Spasm of the biliary tracts secondary to cholesterol stone obstruction:
Incorrect: Spasm of the biliary tract secondary to obstruction of the common bile duct is seen in patients with choledocholithiasis. Although cholesterol gallstones are the most common stones found in the gallbladder, this patient’s underlying condition predisposes him to a different type of stone composition. 
❌ Fibrotic and calcified gallbladder:
Incorrect: Porcelain gallbladder refers to a fibrotic and calcified gallbladder that occurs after recurrent episodes of cholecystitis. Although this patient’s current condition may predispose him to developing porcelain gallbladder, it most commonly presents much later in life (usually around the 6th decade).

A 35-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of abdominal pain that began 18-hours ago. In addition, the patient endorses nausea and one episode of non-bloody non-bilious emesis. Past medical history is notable for three uncomplicated vaginal deliveries and abdominal pain that is exacerbated by fatty meals. On arrival, temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), blood pressure is 130/78 mmHg, heart rate is 76/min, and respiratory rate is 17/min. Abdominal exam reveals right upper quadrant and epigastric tenderness. Cardiovascular and pulmonary exams are non-contributory. Laboratory testing reveals the findings shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the work-up of this patient’s condition?  

 Laboratory Value   Result (U.S. conventional units)  Results (SI units)    Result (U.S. conventional units)  Results (SI units)  
 Hemoglobin  12.7 g/dL  127 g/L 
 Leukocyte Count  10,000/mm3  10*109/L 
 Total Bilirubin  3.2 mg/dL  54.72 µmol/L 
 Conjugated Bilirubin  2.5 mg/dL  42.75 µmol/L 
 Aspartate Aminotransferase  72 U/L  72 U/L 
 Alanine Aminotransferase  77 U/L  77 U/L
questions.solution:
This patient has right upper quadrant pain, elevated liver enzymes, and a conjugated hyperbilirubinemia in the setting of a probable history of gallstones. These factors raise concern for choledocholithiasis, which is the presence of stones within the common bile duct.   

Patients can present with right upper quadrant (RUQ) pain, nausea, and vomiting. In addition, patients can develop pruritus and jaundice secondary to biliary tract obstruction. Laboratory testing will reveal elevated liver enzymes and a conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.   

If the obstruction occurs distal to where the pancreatic duct joints the common bile duct, then patients can develop pancreatitis, which manifests with epigastric pain. In this case, laboratory testing will also reveal elevated lipase and amylase levels.  

The first step in diagnosis is to perform a RUQ ultrasound, which will show dilated biliary ducts. If the ultrasound is negative but clinical suspicion is high, then further imaging such as magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) should be performed.  



Option Analysis

❌ Obtain abdominal CT:
Incorrect: This patient has right upper quadrant pain, elevated liver enzymes, and a conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. These symptoms raise concerns for choledocholithiasis.   Abdominal CTs can detect many pathologies in the upper abdomen, but they expose patients to unnecessary ionizing radiation when the primary concern focuses on the common bile duct. Moreover, many gallstones are isodense to bile, making it difficult to visualize them on CT. As a result, ultrasound is the preferred first-line imaging modality.  
❌ Order abdominal radiograph:
Incorrect: This patient has right upper quadrant pain, elevated liver enzymes, and a conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, which raises concerns for a gallstone-related etiology (e.g., choledocholithiasis, ascending cholangitis). However, most gallstones are radiolucent. As a result, x-rays are rarely used in the work-up of gallstone-related etiologies.
❌ Perform endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography:
Incorrect: An endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) can be used in the work-up and treatment of patients with choledocolithiasis. However, most patients (including the one in this vignette) should first get an ultrasound. The exceptions are high risk patients, such as those who have a total bilirubin level exceeding 4 mg/dL or patients with acute cholangitis. These patients can proceed directly to ERCP. 
✅ Perform right upper quadrant ultrasound:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Order urease breath test:
Incorrect: A urease breath test is used in the work-up of a suspected Helicobacter pylori infection. Patients with this infection are at increased risk of developing peptic ulcers, which can present as epigastric pain that is exacerbated by meals. However, a peptic ulcer would not explain the patients elevated liver enzymes or conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to sudden onset right upper quadrant abdominal pain that began several hours ago. The patient has a past medical history significant for sickle cell disease, and he underwent a splenectomy at the age of 18. He does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. Temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), blood pressure is 124/84 mmHg, and pulse is 92/min. Physical examination shows a thin man in mild distress. Abdominal examination reveals inspiratory arrest during palpation of the right upper quadrant. Laboratory studies are shown below. An ultrasound is performed and reveals a normal common bile duct with concomitant gallbladder wall thickening and free fluid around the gallbladder. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?  

 Laboratory value  Result (U.S. conventional units)  Results (SI units)
 Hemoglobin  13.5 g/dL  135 g/L 
 Leukocyte count  13,000 mm3  13 *10^9/L 
 Total bilirubin  1.1 mg/dL  18.81 µmol/L 
 Direct bilirubin  0.4 mg/dL  6.84 µmol/L 
 Alanine aminotransferase  31 U/L  31 U/L 
 Aspartate aminotransferase  36 U/L  36 U/L 
 Lipase  55 U/L  55 U/L 
 Alkaline phosphatase   55 U/L  55 U/L
questions.solution:
This patient with a chronic hemolytic anemia (sickle cell disease) is presenting with fever and acute right upper quadrant pain; in conjunction with his laboratory values showing leukocytosis, and ultrasound imaging demonstrating a thickened gallbladder wall and pericholecystic fluid, he likely has acute cholecystitis, the most common complication of cholelithiasis. In patients with chronic hemolytic anemias (e.g., sickle cell disease, hereditary spherocytosis), the excess unconjugated bilirubin from the lysed red blood cells results in increased liver uptake and conjugation of bilirubin, ultimately leading to the precipitation of bilirubin into black pigment gallstones.  

Acute cholecystitis is an acute inflammation of the gallbladder caused by obstruction of the cystic duct. When the cystic duct becomes obstructed by a stone, there is distension and inflammation of the gallbladder, triggering an inflammatory response within the gallbladder. Clinical features typically include intense RUQ pain, fever, and nausea. Additionally, this patient demonstrated a positive Murphy sign (sudden inspiratory pause upon palpation of the RUQ). Laboratory findings typically demonstrate leukocytosis. Marked elevation in the serum total bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase concentrations are not common in uncomplicated acute cholecystitis, since obstruction of bile flow is limited to the gallbladder (mild elevations may be present, however).  

Diagnosis relies on a transabdominal ultrasound that helps to visualize the gallbladder. Typical findings in acute cholecystitis include a positive sonographic Murphy sign (sudden inspiratory arrest upon placing the ultrasound probe directly on the gallbladder), gallbladder wall thickening and pericholecystic fluid (hypoechoic free fluid around the gallbladder). If an ultrasound is inconclusive, a HIDA scan (cholescintigraphy) can be performed, in which a radioactive tracer is injected intravenously; normally, the radioactive tracer would fill the gallbladder, but in cases of cystic duct obstruction, the gallbladder would not be visualized.  



Option Analysis

❌ Acute cholangitis:
Incorrect: Acute cholangitis is an ascending infection of the biliary tract due to an obstruction, most commonly from a gallstone. Although it also presents with right upper quadrant pain, fever, and leukocytosis, patients have evidence of cholestasis (elevated direct bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase) on laboratory testing, as well as biliary dilation on imaging.
✅ Acute cholecystitis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Splenic sequestration crisis:
Incorrect: Splenic sequestration crisis is a vaso-occlusive episode in the spleen that results in pooling of large amounts of blood in the spleen, resulting in acute left upper quadrant pain, anemia, and signs of intravascular volume depletion (e.g. hypotension). This patient has pain localized to the right upper quadrant and normal hemoglobin levels, suggesting a different diagnosis. Additionally, he had his spleen removed, which makes this diagnosis unlikely. 
❌ Gallstone pancreatitis:
Incorrect: Gallstones are the most common cause of acute pancreatitis in the United States. Patients with acute pancreatitis typically present with acute, persistent epigastric abdominal pain that radiates to the back. In contrast, this patient has pain localized to the right upper quadrant; in addition, the laboratory values showing normal lipase levels essentially excludes pancreatitis as a diagnosis.
❌ Vaso-occlusive crisis:
Incorrect: Vaso-occlusive crisis (sickle cell crisis) is a major complication of sickle cell disease that is characterized by severe pain and tissue ischemia. Episodes typically present with severe deep bone pain and dactylitis (acute pain and swelling in the hands and feet). This patient’s abdominal ultrasound, however, suggests a different diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman is brought to the hospital for evaluation of abdominal pain that began 28 hours ago. She describes the pain as constant and stabbing. In addition, the patient has had several episodes of emesis. Medical history is notable for three uncomplicated spontaneous vaginal deliveries. Temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), blood pressure is 120/73 mmHg, pulse is 80/min, and body mass index is 31 kg/m2. Two large-bore intravenous catheters are placed, and the patient is started on normal saline. An abdominal ultrasound is performed, but the findings are inconclusive. A CT scan is subsequently performed, revealing the findings shown below. Physical exam is notable for tenderness in the right upper abdominal quadrant and dry mucosal membranes. No jaundice or scleral icterus is observed. Which of the following medications will be most useful in managing this patient’s condition?  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient has right upper quadrant pain, fever, and imaging revealing a gallstone in the common bile duct, which raises concerns for acute cholangitis. The patient has a history of multiple prior pregnancies and an elevated BMI, which are risk factors for developing gallstones. Gallstones can obstruct the common bile duct, causing biliary stasis and creating an environment for the bacteria that have ascended the biliary tract to proliferate, resulting in acute cholangitis.  

Acute cholangitis is a potentially life-threatening condition. The first step in management is to ensure the patient is hemodynamically stable, which involves placing at least two large bore intravenous catheters and initiating intravenous fluids. In addition, patients should be started on antibiotics with coverage for gram-negative and anaerobic bacteria (e.g., piperacillin-tazobactam, or ceftriaxone plus metronidazole). Patients should also be made NPO.   

Laboratory testing, such as a complete blood count, liver enzymes, and bilirubin levels, can be ordered. For patients with a high clinical suspicion, such as those presenting with the Charcot triad or Reynolds pentad, endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) should be directly performed for diagnosis and treatment. For patients with lower clinical suspicion, a right upper quadrant (RUQ) ultrasound should be performed to evaluate for obstruction, common bile duct dilation, and thickened bile duct walls. If the ultrasound is inconclusive, a CT can be subsequently performed. Once the diagnosis is confirmed, patients should undergo ERCP for treatment.  

Option Analysis

✅ Piperacillin-tazobactam:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Ceftriaxone:
Incorrect: This patient has right upper quadrant pain, fever, and imaging revealing a gallstone in the common bile duct. She likely has ascending cholangitis, which is most often caused by gram-negative and anaerobic pathogens. While ceftriaxone, a third-generation cephalosporin, has gram-native coverage, it lacks anaerobic coverage.   
❌ Vancomycin:
Incorrect: This patient most likely has ascending cholangitis, which is usually secondary to gram-negative and anaerobic pathogens. Vancomycin provides only gram-positive coverage. As a result, it would not be useful in treating ascending cholangitis. 
❌ Albendazole:
Incorrect: Infection by the Echinococcus tapeworms can result in the formation of hydatid cysts, which often manifest in the liver. The cyst can have eggshell calcification, meaning the cyst appears as a calcified (white) rim and fluid-filled (dark) center on CT. This classic finding is absent on the patient’s scan, and the patient’s history of multiparity and obesity are more concerning for a gallstone-related etiology.  
❌ Norepinephrine:
Incorrect: Norepinephrine is a vasopressor that can be used in patients with septic shock. This patient has fever and findings that are concerning for acute cholangitis, which can lead to sepsis. However, her blood pressure is within normal limits, and therefore, she does not need to be started on a pressor at this time.

A 41-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation of abdominal pain that started one-day ago. In addition, the patient has had one episode of emesis. Past medical history is notable for type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and abdominal pain that is worse after heavy meals. Temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), blood pressure is 145/80 mmHg, heart rate is 77/min, and respiratory rate is 19/min. Abdominal exam reveals right upper quadrant pain that is elicited with palpation. Cardiovascular and pulmonary exams are non-contributory. Laboratory testing reveals the findings shown below. Endoscopy is performed to relieve the obstruction. The patient is currently not in any pain or discomfort. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?  

 Laboratory Value   Result (U.S. conventional units)  Results (SI units)    Result (U.S. conventional units)  Results (SI units)  
 Hemoglobin  13.0 g/dL  130 g/L 
 Leukocyte Count  10,400/mm3  10.4 * 109/L 
 Total Bilirubin  3.0 mg/dL  51.3 µmol/L 
 Conjugated Bilirubin  2.5 mg/dL  42.75 µmol/L 
 Aspartate Aminotransferase  81 U/L  81 U/L 
 Alanine Aminotransferase  79 U/L  79 U/L 
 Alkaline Phosphatase  120 U/L  120 U/L
questions.solution:
This patient has right upper quadrant pain, elevated liver enzymes and alkaline phosphatase, and conjugated hyperbilirubinemia with a history of postprandial pain that is most likely secondary to gallstones. These findings are consistent with the presentation of choledocholithiasis, which occurs when a stone enters and obstructs the common bile duct.

The first step in management is to ensure hemodynamic stability. Even in stable patients (such as this patient), this priority should be achieved by placing at least two large-bore intravenous catheters and starting intravenous fluids. In addition, patients should not be allowed to consume any food or liquids by mouth (NPO).   

Once the patient is stable, imaging can be performed to make the diagnosis. The first test is a right upper quadrant (RUQ) ultrasound, which may show an obstructing gallstone, common bile duct dilation, and thickened bile duct walls. If the ultrasound does not reveal any findings but clinical suspicion is high, additional imaging such as magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) should be performed.    

Once the diagnosis has been confirmed, treatment can be achieved via endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) to remove the obstructing gallstone. Lastly, a cholecystectomy should be performed to prevent future episodes of choledocholithiasis.  

Option Analysis

❌ Discharge patient from hospital:
Incorrect: This patient has right upper quadrant pain, elevated liver enzymes, and a conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, which raises concerns for choledocholithiasis. Endoscopy can be performed to remove the obstructing gallstone. However, patients would also need a cholecystectomy to prevent future episodes of choledocholithiasis.
❌ Obtain serum lipase levels:
Incorrect: Endoscopic removal of the obstructing gallstone can cause tissue injury and result in pancreatitis as a complication. However, this patient has no signs of pancreatitis (e.g., epigastric pain radiating to the back, periumbilical bruising), so it is not necessary to obtain a serum lipase level at this time.
✅ Perform cholecystectomy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Initiation of piperacillin-tazobactam therapy:
Incorrect: Antibiotic prophylaxis can be given during endoscopic procedures. However, antibiotics are generally not required after the procedure unless the patient has cholecystitis, cholangitis, or another infection. In contrast, this patient does not have fever, leukocytosis, or signs of sepsis (e.g., tachycardia, hypotension), making the likelihood of an infection low.
❌ Administration of indomethacin:
Incorrect: Pancreatitis is a side-effect of endoscopic gallstone removal. This side-effect is due to a combination of mechanical injury from instrumentation of the pancreatic duct and hydrostatic injury from contrast injection. Administering NSAIDs before the procedure can reduce inflammation and the risk of pancreatitis. However, administering NSAIDs after the procedure would not yield this benefit.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman comes to the clinic complaining of intense abdominal pain for the past several weeks. She states that the pain typically occurs in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen an hour after eating meals, and it is associated with nausea. Past medical history is significant for 3 spontaneous vaginal deliveries and obesity. The patient does not use alcohol, tobacco, or illicit drugs. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 122/82 mmHg, and pulse is 83/min. BMI is 38 kg/m2. On physical examination, the patient is resting comfortably on the examination table. Abdominal examination shows mild tenderness to palpation in the right upper quadrant and epigastrium. The remainder of the examination is within normal limits. Leukocyte count is 6,000/mm3 and hemoglobin is 13.6 g/dL. Liver enzymes are within normal limits. Which of the following is the best next step in evaluation of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with classic signs of symptoms of biliary colic secondary to gallstones. Cholesterol gallstones form when there is an increase in cholesterol concentration or decrease in bile salt concentration of the bile; this ultimately leads to precipitation of cholesterol in the form of gallstones, also known as cholelithiasis.  

Most gallstones are asymptomatic and are often found incidentally on abdominal imaging (e.g. ultrasound for other purposes). When symptomatic, the main presenting symptom is biliary colic, which occurs when the stone blocks the cystic duct. This causes pressure in the gallbladder to increase as it tries to contract, leading to pain in the right upper quadrant or epigastrium that radiates to the right shoulder (due to referred pain from diaphragmatic irritation). The pain often occurs after eating a large or fatty meal and lasts for 1-5 hours before subsiding as the gallbladder relaxes.  

If gallstones are suspected based on the symptoms and history of the patient, confirmation of the diagnosis can be done with a right upper quadrant ultrasound. Ultrasounds are the gold standard study for diagnosing gallstones since they are quick, noninvasive, inexpensive and sensitive enough to detect even tiny stones, and they can additionally detect the dilation of the gallbladder and bile duct. Ultrasound findings typically demonstrate posterior acoustic shadows (indicative of the gallstones), as well as sludge (which corresponds to thickened bile).   

Option Analysis

❌ Abdominal x-ray:
Incorrect: An abdominal x-ray may be helpful in determining if there is perforation of a hollow organ leading to pneumoperitoneum; however, this complication would present with severe abdominal pain, diffuse guarding, and rebound tenderness. Plain radiographs have a very low sensitivity for gallstones, and therefore, another imaging modality is preferred. 
❌ HIDA scan :
Incorrect: Hepatobiliary iminodiacetic acid (HIDA) scan, also known as a cholescintigraphy, is used to diagnose acute cholecystitis if ultrasound is inconclusive. Since it is a relatively invasive test (requires intravenous injection of a radiotracer), another less invasive test should be performed first. 
❌ Serum lipase:
Incorrect: Elevated serum lipase is a sensitive and specific serum marker found in patients with acute pancreatitis. Patients with acute pancreatitis typically present with acute, persistent epigastric abdominal pain that radiates to the back. In contrast, this patient is presenting with recurrent episodes of postprandial right upper quadrant pain, suggestive of a different underlying condition.
✅ Abdominal ultrasound :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography:
Incorrect: Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is recommended in patients with gallstone pancreatitis. These patients typically present with nausea, vomiting, leukocytosis, and elevated ALT levels (>150 U/L).

questions.text: A 41-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation of abdominal pain that began seven hours ago. The pain is most prominent in the epigastric region and radiates to the back. In addition, he has had two episodes of emesis. Medical history is notable for hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus, which is well controlled with metformin. Temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), blood pressure is 137/86 mmHg, pulse is 92/min, and respiratory rate is 18/min. Abdominal exam reveals tenderness in the right upper quadrant and epigastrium. The mucosal membranes appear dry, and the patient has a delayed capillary refill time. The remainder of the physical exam is unremarkable. Right upper quadrant ultrasound reveals the presence of one gallstone in the gallbladder and another obstructing the common bile duct. Laboratory testing reveals a lipase of 820 U/L and amylase of 650 U/L. Endoscopy is performed and successfully removes the stone obstructing the common bile duct. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Order CT evaluation of pancreatic pseudocysts

questions.solution:
This patient has epigastric pain radiating to the back, serum amylase and lipase levels greater than three times the upper limit, and the presence of cholelithiasis on imaging. These findings are diagnostic for gallstone pancreatitis, which arises when a gallstone obstructs the common bile duct and impairs pancreatic enzyme outflow.

The first step in management is to stabilize the patient, which involves first placing at least two large-bore intravenous catheters. Afterwards, patients should be started on intravenous fluids and, if necessary, intravenous analgesics (e.g. fentanyl). Patients should not be allowed to consume anything by mouth (NPO). Laboratory testing (e.g., liver enzymes, bilirubin levels, trending lipase levels) should also be ordered.    

After the patient is hemodynamically stable, a right upper quadrant (RUQ) ultrasound should be performed to evaluate for gallstones. In patients meeting one of the following criteria, an endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) should be done within 24 hours to relieve the obstruction:    

1) If the patient has concurrent cholangitis  
2) If RUQ ultrasound reveals a stone obstructing the common bile duct or dilation of the duct  
3) If liver enzymes and bilirubin levels are increasing  

If none of these criteria are met, an ERCP is not necessary. However, all patients with gallstone pancreatitis should undergo cholecystectomy prior to discharge from the hospital to prevent recurrent episodes.  

Option Analysis

❌ Discharge patient from hospital:
Incorrect: This patient has right upper quadrant pain, as well as elevated lipase and amylase levels, which raises concerns for gallstone pancreatitis. Endoscopy can be performed to remove the obstructing gallstone. However, patients would also need a cholecystectomy to prevent recurrent episodes of pancreatitis.
❌ Administration of piperacillin-tazobactam:
Incorrect: Piperacillin-tazobactam is a broad spectrum antibiotic that has gram-negative and anaerobic coverage. It can be used to treat infections arising from pancreatic necrosis. In addition, the agent can be used to treat gallstone-related etiologies such as emphysematous cholecystitis and acute cholangitis. However, this patient has no signs of infection (e.g., fever), and the use of prophylactic antibiotics is not recommended in sterile pancreatitis.
✅ Perform laparoscopic cholecystectomy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Order CT evaluation of pancreatic pseudocysts:
Incorrect: Pancreatic pseudocysts are collections of fluid rich in pancreatic enzymes, blood, and necrotic tissue. They are a complication of pancreatitis and can manifest with abdominal pain and bloating. However, this patient currently has no cyst-related symptoms. Moreover, most cysts develop more than four weeks after the initial episode of pancreatitis.  
❌ Perform percutaneous gallstone extraction:
Incorrect: Severely ill patients, such as those with myocardial infarction or end-stage renal disease, may be unsuitable candidates for surgical cholecystectomy. In these patients, a percutaneous gallstone extraction can be performed as an alternative. However, this patient has no contraindications to a surgical cholecystectomy.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman is brought to the emergency room because of abdominal pain that began one-day ago. She also endorses fever, nausea, and vomiting. Past medical history is notable for hypertension, choledocholithiasis, and osteoarthritis. She underwent a left total knee arthroplasty four-months ago. The procedure was complicated by excess blood loss and a transfusion was required. On arrival, temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), blood pressure is 115/76 mmHg, and pulse is 96/min. Abdominal exam is notable for pain that is elicited with palpation of the right upper quadrant and epigastrium. Jaundice and scleral icterus are observed. Cardiac and pulmonary exams are non-contributory. Laboratory testing reveals an aspartate aminotransferase level of 75 U/L and alanine aminotransferase level of 72 U/L. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has right upper quadrant (RUQ) pain, fever, and jaundice in the setting of a history of gallstones, which raises concerns for acute cholangitis. It is a potentially life-threatening condition and the work-up process varies depending on the extent of clinical suspicion.  

For patients with high clinical suspicion for acute cholangitis, such as those presenting with the Charcot triad (RUQ pain, fever, and jaundice) or Reynolds pentad (Charcot triad, hypotension, altered mental status), endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) should be performed. ERCP can confirm the diagnosis and treat the condition by removing the gallstone via sphincterotomy. Of note, the patient in this vignette has the Charcot triad.  

For patients with lower clinical suspicion, a right upper quadrant ultrasound should be performed to evaluate for obstruction, common bile duct dilation, and thickened bile duct walls, which, if present in the setting of fever, would raise clinical suspicion for acute cholangitis. If the ultrasound is inconclusive, an abdominal CT can be performed. Once the diagnosis is confirmed, patients should also undergo ERCP for gallstone removal.



Option Analysis

❌ Order upright abdominal x-ray:
Incorrect: This patient has right upper quadrant pain, fever, and elevated liver enzymes, which raises concerns for a gallstone-related etiology (e.g., cholecystitis, acute cholangitis). However, most gallstones are radiolucent, and as a result, x-rays are rarely used in the work-up of gallstone-related etiologies.
❌ Obtain hepatitis C serology titers:
Incorrect: This patient had a recent blood transfusion, which is a risk factor for contracting hepatitis C. Hepatitis C may cause elevated liver enzymes and right upper quadrant pain. However, transmission of hepatitis C via blood transfusions has been very rare since universal screening was begun in 1992. Furthermore, patients with viral hepatitis often have markedly elevated aminotransferase levels that are 10-20 times the upper limit of normal. Lastly, the patient’s history of choledocholithiasis raises suspicions for a gallstone-related etiology. 
✅ Perform endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Perform right upper quadrant ultrasound:
Incorrect: The patient has the Charcot triad, which consists of right upper quadrant pain, fever, and jaundice. As a result, clinical suspicion is high for acute cholangitis, and the patient should proceed to endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP). In contrast, for patients with lower clinical suspicion, an ultrasound should first be performed to confirm the diagnosis before ERCP is performed.
❌ Order hepatobiliary scintigraphy scan:
Incorrect: A hepatobiliary scintigraphy scan, also termed HIDA scan, can be used to evaluate the biliary tree. It can be used in the work-up of certain patients with inconclusive ultrasound results. For instance, in the case of cholecystitis, an inconclusive ultrasound result should be followed-up by a HIDA scan. However, the patient in this vignette most likely has acute cholangitis and the next step would be to follow-up with a CT scan.

This patient presents with jaundice, right upper quadrant pain, nausea, and vomiting in conjunction with laboratory results showing a cholestatic pattern; he most likely has choledocholithiasis.   

Choledocholithiasis refers to the presence of gallstones obstructing the common bile duct. Patients typically present with right upper quadrant or epigastric pain, nausea, vomiting, and jaundice. Laboratory results may show a cholestatic pattern manifested as an elevation of ALP, GGT, direct bilirubin, and/or AST/ALT.  

Diagnosis can be made with the following imaging techniques:  
● Transabdominal ultrasound, which would show a dilated common bile duct  
● Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP), which is both therapeutic and diagnostic  
● Endoscopic ultrasound (EUS)  
● Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP)  
● Intraoperative cholangiography or ultrasonography  



Option Analysis

❌ Distended bowel loops on abdominal x-ray:
Incorrect: These findings can be seen in patients with bowel obstruction. Patients with bowel obstruction typically present with diffuse abdominal pain, distention, and hyperactive bowel sounds. This patient’s presentation suggests another diagnosis.   
❌ Failure to visualize radiotracer in the gallbladder on hepatobiliary iminodiacetic acid (HIDA) scan:
Incorrect: These findings can be seen in patients with cholecystitis. In healthy individuals, the radiotracer is injected into the bloodstream, absorbed by the liver, then travels with the bile into the gallbladder and the small intestine. Failure to visualize radioactive tracer within the gallbladder during HIDA scan is considered diagnostic for cholecystitis. Patients with uncomplicated cholecystitis typically present with right upper quadrant pain, fever, and leukocytosis; however, liver enzymes are normal and no jaundice is expected.  
❌ Diffuse parenchymal enlargement of the pancreas on CT contrast:
Incorrect: These findings can be seen in patients with pancreatitis. Patients with acute pancreatitis typically experience acute epigastric pain radiating to the back, elevation of serum amylase or lipase to 3x upper limit of normal, and/or characteristic enlargement of the pancreas on CT with contrast. This patient’s laboratory results and presentation suggest another diagnosis. 
✅ Dilated common bile duct on magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Gallbladder wall thickening and pericholecystic fluid on abdominal ultrasound :
Incorrect: These findings suggest cholecystitis. Patients with uncomplicated cholecystitis typically present with right upper quadrant pain, fever, and leukocytosis; however, liver enzymes are normal and no jaundice is expected.

On arrival, temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), blood pressure is 112/73 mmHg, pulse is 110/min, and respiratory rate is 18/min. Abdominal exam is notable for pain and crepitus in the right upper quadrant. The patient has dry mucosal membranes and a delayed capillary refill time. This patient has right upper quadrant pain and crepitus, fever, and leukocytosis, which raises concern for emphysematous cholecystitis. The condition occurs when vascular compromise of the cystic artery results in gallbladder wall ischemia. Necrosis and infection by gas-forming organisms (e.g., Clostridium perfringens, certain Escherichia coli species) subsequently occur. The patient’s history of diabetes mellitus and vascular disease are risk factors for developing the condition.  

The first step in management is to ensure hemodynamic stability. This goal can be achieved by placing at least two large-bore intravenous catheters and initiating intravenous fluids. Patients should also be started on broad-spectrum antibiotics with gram-negative and anaerobic coverage (e.g., piperacillin-tazobactam, metronidazole and ceftriaxone).    
The condition can be diagnosed via a CT scan, which can reveal gas in the gallbladder wall (Figure 1) and an air-fluid-level (Figure 1). In contrast, ultrasonography is less accurate, since air within the gallbladder walls can interfere with the organ’s visualization.  

Patients should be treated with an emergency cholecystectomy to remove the necrotic and infected gallbladder.

Option Analysis

❌ Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography:
Incorrect: Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) uses a combination of endoscopy and fluoroscopy to diagnose and treat certain biliary tree conditions. Such conditions range from sphincter of Oddi dysfunction to acute cholangitis. However, ERCP is not used in the treatment of emphysematous cholecystitis.
❌ Perform endovascular aneurysm repair:
Incorrect: A ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) can manifest with abdominal, back, or flank pain. The patient’s history of smoking places him at increased risk. However, an AAA would not explain the patient’s fever, leukocytosis, or abdominal crepitus.
✅ Perform emergency cholecystectomy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Administration of vancomycin monotherapy:
Incorrect: This patient has right upper quadrant pain and crepitus in the setting of a history of diabetes mellitus and vascular disease, which raises concern for emphysematous cholecystitis. The condition is most often due to infection of the gallbladder by gram-negative and anaerobic pathogens. In contrast, vancomycin has predominantly gram-positive coverage and would not be useful in treating this condition.  
❌ Perform endoscopic thermocoagulation:
Incorrect: This technique can be used to treat bleeding from peptic ulcers and other sources of upper gastrointestinal bleeding. A peptic ulcer can manifest with pain in the upper abdominal quadrants. However, it would be unusual for a peptic ulcer to cause abdominal crepitus, fever, or leukocytosis.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department following a motor vehicle accident. She is minimally responsive, and injuries include a left femoral fracture and various ecchymoses across the chest. The patient receives multiple blood product transfusions and undergoes repair of the femoral fracture. The patient is intubated and admitted to the intensive care unit. On the 4th day in the intensive care unit, she remains minimally responsive. Temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), blood pressure is 120/82 mmHg, and pulse is 90/min. Palpation of the right upper quadrant of the abdomen elicits groaning and facial grimacing. No rebound tenderness or involuntary guarding is noted. Ultrasound imaging reveals a normal common bile duct with concomitant gallbladder wall thickening and pericholecystic fluid, but no gallstones are visualized. No gallbladder perforations, intramural gas, or necrosis are noted. In addition to administration of intravenous fluids and empiric antibiotics, which of the following is the next best step in management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This severely ill patient is presenting with a fever and acute right upper quadrant pain; in conjunction with the history of trauma and multiple blood transfusions, and ultrasound imaging demonstrating a thickened gallbladder wall with no visible gallstones, she likely has acute acalculous cholecystitis. This is more common in elderly patients, those who are already seriously ill, or those who have been on total parenteral nutrition (TPN) for a prolonged period of time. The cause is gallbladder hypomotility and subsequent bile stasis which concentrates the bile, creating a toxic effect on the gallbladder walls, resulting in necrosis and inflammation.  

Acalculous cholecystitis is a serious condition that can ultimately lead to sepsis and death if untreated. Since these patients are often severely ill, there must be a low threshold for clinical suspicion. Patients may initially present with vague abdominal pain, fever, and leukocytosis on laboratory examination. The best initial step involves abdominal imaging, most commonly with a right upper quadrant ultrasound. Common radiologic signs of acalculous cholecystitis include gallbladder wall thickening, pericholecystic fluid, and the absence of gallstones. If complications are present, such as necrosis, perforation, or emphysematous cholecystitis, an emergency cholecystectomy should be performed. However, if these complications are not present, percutaneous cholecystostomy should be done under radiologic guidance. If patients show improvement over the next several days, another RUQ ultrasound can be done to look for gallstones or biliary sludge. If either are present, an elective cholecystectomy can be done when the patient recovers from their illness. However, if neither are present, a cholecystectomy is not needed.  



Option Analysis

❌ Observation and expectant management :
Incorrect: This patient is presenting with acalculous cholecystitis, which requires a definitive treatment. Observation and expectant management are not appropriate for this patient. 
❌ Open laparotomy :
Incorrect: Open laparotomy can be considered in patients presenting with signs of peritonitis (e.g. guarding and rebound tenderness). However, this patient has pain localized to the RUQ, and therefore, a more conservative approach is appropriate. 
❌ Emergent cholecystectomy :
Incorrect: In some patients with acute acalculous cholecystitis, severe complications can occur, such as gallbladder necrosis, emphysematous cholecystitis, and gallbladder perforation. These would be indications for an emergency cholecystectomy; however, none of these are present in this patient, and therefore a more conservative approach is warranted.
✅ Percutaneous drainage of the gallbladder:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography :
Incorrect: Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is a diagnostic and therapeutic procedure that helps visualize and remove a problematic gallstone. ERCP is commonly used in cases of gallstone complications, such as pancreatitis or choledocholithiasis; however, this patient has acalculous cholecystitis, and therefore, another approach is more appropriate.

The patient does not smoke and consumes 3-4 beers per month. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), blood pressure is 152/93 mmHg, pulse is 83/min, and respiratory rate is 19/min. Physical exam reveals tenderness in the right upper quadrant and epigastric regions of the abdomen. Bowel sounds are normal, and no hepatosplenomegaly is noted. questions.solution:
This patient has epigastric pain radiating to the back, an elevated lipase level, and likely history of gallstones. These findings are suggestive of gallstone pancreatitis. Gallstone disease is the most common cause of acute pancreatitis in the Western world. The condition arises when a gallstone enters the common bile duct and obstructs outflow from the pancreatic duct. As a result, pancreatic enzymes cannot be excreted, and they instead begin to autodigest the organ’s parenchyma, resulting in inflammation and, if severe, necrosis. Patients can present with epigastric pain radiating to the back, nausea/vomiting, and skin findings such as Cullen sign (periumbilical ecchymosis) or Grey Turner sign (flank ecchymosis).  

The diagnosis of gallstone pancreatitis can be made if the patient has: 1) acute upper abdominal pain radiating to the back; 2) amylase or lipase levels three-times the upper limit of normal; and 3) the presence of gallstones on imaging. In addition, patients may have elevated liver transaminase and bilirubin levels secondary to biliary tract obstruction and bile backflow.  

In regards to imaging, the first step is to visualize the gallstones using a right upper quadrant (RUQ) ultrasound, which is inexpensive, sensitive, and widely available. An alternative option is an abdominal CT scan. However, this modality is less preferred, since it unnecessarily exposes patients to ionizing radiation.  



Option Analysis

❌ Obtain serum amylase levels:
Incorrect: This patient has epigastric pain radiating to the back, lipase levels greater than three times the upper limit, and a likely history of gallstones. These findings are highly suggestive of gallstone pancreatitis. Amylase is a less specific marker of pancreatitis than lipase, and it is not needed on top of a lipase level to make the diagnosis.  
❌ Initiation of piperacillin-tazobactam therapy:
Incorrect: Piperacillin-tazobactam is a broad spectrum antibiotic that has gram-negative and anaerobic coverage. It can be used to treat infections arising from pancreatic necrosis. However, this patient has no signs of infection at this time (e.g. fever), and the use of prophylactic antibiotics is not recommended in sterile pancreatitis.
❌ Perform endoscopic gallstone removal:
Incorrect: This patient likely has gallstone pancreatitis. Endoscopic techniques can be used to remove stones obstructing the common bile duct. However, a right upper quadrant ultrasound should first be performed to first confirm the diagnosis.
❌ Order computed tomography of the abdomen:
Incorrect: This patient likely has gallstone pancreatitis. Computed tomography can be used to diagnose patients with pancreatitis and may reveal the presence of gallstones in the common bile duct. However, ultrasound is the preferred technique for visualizing the biliary tree, and therefore it is the first-line imaging modality for patients with gallstone-related etiologies. 
✅ Perform abdominal ultrasound:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her partner after she experienced a sudden onset of right upper quadrant abdominal pain that began several hours ago. She also describes nausea and states she had a single episode of vomiting, which prompted her to come to the hospital. She describes similar episodes in the past that self-resolved after several hours, but this time, the pain persisted and worsened. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), blood pressure is 122/68 mmHg, and pulse is 104/min. Physical examination reveals intense pain on palpation of the right upper quadrant, as well as diffuse rebound and guarding. An ultrasound is performed and reveals a normal common bile duct with concomitant gallbladder wall thickening and free fluid around the gallbladder. An abdominal CT is performed and reveals a perforation of the gallbladder. In addition to administration of broad-spectrum antibiotics and intravenous fluids, which of the following is the next best step in management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with fever, acute right upper quadrant pain, and peritonitis (e.g., rebound, guarding); in conjunction with ultrasound imaging demonstrating a thickened gallbladder wall, she likely has acute calculous cholecystitis, the most common complication of cholelithiasis. Additionally, the abdominal CT imaging revealed a perforated gallbladder, making this a surgical emergency.   

Acute cholecystitis is an acute inflammation of the gallbladder caused by obstruction of the cystic duct. When the cystic duct becomes obstructed by a stone, there is distension and inflammation of the gallbladder triggering an inflammatory response within the gallbladder. Clinical features typically include intense RUQ pain, fever, and nausea. In patients with uncomplicated and mild cases of acute cholecystitis, treatment consists of intravenous fluid therapy and empiric intravenous antibiotics (e.g., ceftriaxone with metronidazole, piperacillin-tazobactam). Patients with clinical improvement will also need an elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy within 72 hours of symptom onset (preferably during the same admission) to prevent future recurrence or complications.  

In certain cases of acute cholecystitis, gallbladder gangrene/necrosis, gallbladder perforation, or emphysematous cholecystitis can occur, which necessitates an emergent cholecystectomy. These complications should be considered in patients with progressive symptoms and signs, such as high fever, hemodynamic instability, and/or peritonitis (such as in this patient).  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Observation and expectant management :
Incorrect: This patient is presenting with signs of acute cholecystitis, as well as peritonitis (e.g., rebound, guarding). Observation and expectant management is not appropriate in this patient whose abdominal imaging revealed a perforated gallbladder. 
❌ Ursodeoxycholic acid therapy:
Incorrect: Therapy with ursodeoxycholic acid may be necessary in patients with symptomatic gallstones who are poor surgical candidates (e.g., concomitant underlying conditions such as uncontrolled diabetes or congestive heart failure). However, it is not appropriate in this patient presenting with signs of peritonitis and whose abdominal imaging revealed a perforated gallbladder.
❌ Elective cholecystectomy within 72 hours:
Incorrect: An elective cholecystectomy within 72 hours is appropriate in patients with mild cases of acute cholecystitis (e.g., no signs of peritonitis, gallbladder gangrene/necrosis, or gallbladder perforation). 
❌ Cholecystostomy :
Incorrect: Cholecystostomy involves the placement of a tube into the gallbladder to drain fluid, and it is often used as a temporizing measure in patients that cannot undergo cholecystectomy. This patient has no contraindications to surgery and therefore requires a different approach. 
✅ Emergent cholecystectomy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

This patient has right upper quadrant pain, fever, and jaundice. These symptoms raise concern for acute cholangitis, which is an infection of the biliary tree in the setting of biliary obstruction. In addition, the patient has a history of diabetes mellitus and fibrate use. These are risk factors for the development of gallstones, which can potentially obstruct the biliary tract.  

Biliary tract infections are usually caused by gram-negative and anaerobic bacteria from the intestines. The most common is Escherichia coli, which accounts for 25-50% of cases. Additional pathogens include the Klebsiella, Enterococcus, and Enterobacter species.    

Patients should be started on empiric antibiotic regimens with gram-negative and anaerobic coverage. Single-agent regimens include piperacillin-tazobactam or carbapenems. Multi-drug regimens generally consist of a cephalosporin or fluoroquinolone used in combination with metronidazole.  

Option Analysis

❌ Echinococcus granulosus:
Incorrect: Infection by the Echinococcus tapeworms can result in the formation of hydatid cysts, which most often arise in the liver. Large cysts can obstruct biliary outflow, potentially accounting for many of the patient’s laboratory and physical exam findings. However, helminth infections typically cause eosinophilia, whereas this patient’s eosinophil count is within normal limits.  
❌ Clonorchis sinensis:
Incorrect: Clonorchis sinensis is a trematode that is endemic in East and Southeast Asia. The patient’s history of having previously lived in Thailand places her at increased risk. The pathogen can cause right upper quadrant pain, jaundice, and weight loss. However, patients would typically also have eosinophilia. In contrast, this patient’s eosinophil count is within normal limits, and the acute nature of her symptoms suggests another diagnosis.  
❌ Staphylococcus aureus:
Incorrect: This patient has the Charcot triad (i.e. the combination of right upper quadrant abdominal pain, fever, and jaundice), which raises concern for acute cholangitis. The condition is most commonly caused by gram negative and anaerobic bacteria that have entered the biliary tree. In contrast, Staphylococcus aureus is a gram-positive bacteria.   
❌ Hepatitis C virus:
Incorrect: Viral hepatitis can manifest with right upper quadrant pain, jaundice, and elevated liver enzymes. However, patients with hepatitis generally have unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, while this patient has conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, raising concern instead for a biliary tract obstruction. 
✅ Escherichia coli:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.solution:
This patient with severe Crohn disease and prolonged therapy with total parenteral nutrition (TPN) is presenting with fever and acute right upper quadrant pain; in conjunction with her laboratory values showing leukocytosis and her ultrasound imaging demonstrating a thickened gallbladder wall with no visible gallstones, she likely has acute acalculous cholecystitis. This is more common in elderly patients, those who are already seriously ill, or those who have been on TPN for a prolonged period of time. The cause is gallbladder hypomotility and bile stasis which concentrates the bile, making it toxic to the gallbladder walls, eventually leading to inflammation and necrosis. This patient has been on prolonged therapy with TPN, causing bile stasis, which is the likely cause of her acalculous cholecystitis.  

Clinical features typically include intense RUQ pain, fever, and nausea. Additionally, this patient demonstrated a positive sonographic Murphy sign (sudden inspiratory pause upon placing the ultrasound probe on the gallbladder). Laboratory findings typically demonstrate leukocytosis with an increased number of band forms (i.e. left shift). Mild elevations in the serum total bilirubin, alkaline phosphatase, and liver enzymes can also be seen in patients with acalculous cholecystitis.  

The best initial step for diagnosing acute acalculous cholecystitis is an ultrasound of the right upper quadrant. If there are no stones visualized on an ultrasound, or if the diagnosis is uncertain, a CT scan or HIDA scan would be the next appropriate step. Since HIDA scans take longer, it should only be considered in hemodynamically stable patients. For a HIDA scan, a radioactive tracer is injected into a vein, which then enters the bile-producing cells in the liver that will secrete the tracer into bile. The bile carries the tracer through the entire hepatobiliary system and allows visualization; therefore, in acute cholecystitis, the tracer will not fill the gallbladder, indicating a positive test.    

Option Analysis

❌ Ascending infection of the biliary tract:
Incorrect: This describes acute cholangitis, which is characterized by inflammation of the biliary ducts. This condition is most commonly caused by gallstones, which impair bile outflow, causing biliary stasis, and thus creating an environment for the bacteria that have ascended the biliary tract to proliferate. This patient’s imaging shows no gallstones, and the lack of jaundice makes this unlikely. 
❌ Mechanical obstruction of the cystic duct :
Incorrect: This describes calculus cholecystitis, which occurs when a gallstone obstructs the cystic duct and causes gallbladder distention and inflammation. Patients can develop right upper quadrant pain and fever, similar to the patient seen here. However, this patient was not found to have a visible gallstone, which suggests a different diagnosis.  
✅ Gallbladder hypomotility :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Obstruction of the common bile duct:
Incorrect: This answer describes choledocholithiasis, which can cause right upper quadrant pain, nausea/vomiting, and extrahepatic cholestasis. However, the condition is not associated with infection. As a result, patients with choledocholithiasis would not have fever or leukocytosis.
❌ Gallstone obstructing the small bowel:
Incorrect: In cases of gallbladder perforation and fistula formation between an inflamed gallbladder and the bowel, gallstones can pass into the bowel lumen and cause mechanical obstruction. Patients with gallstone ileus typically present with signs of small bowel obstruction, such as abdominal pain and distension, as well as nausea and vomiting. Although this patient’s underlying Crohn disease predisposes her to this condition, ultrasound imaging classically demonstrates pneumobilia (air in the biliary ducts).

questions.text: A 64-year-old woman who is being treated on the floors for NSTEMI complains of fever and abdominal pain on day 3 of her hospitalization that has been complicated by many factors. The patient has a history of obesity, coronary artery disease, hyperlipidemia, diabetes, and hypertension. Temperature is 37.9°C (100.3°F), blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg, and pulse is 101/min. Physical examination reveals tenderness to palpation of the right upper quadrant, and palpation in the right upper quadrant during inspiration causes the patient to stop inspiring. The patient is provided with intravenous fluids and empiric antibiotics. Laboratory results demonstrate leukocytosis with white blood cell count of 18,100 /mm<sup>3</sup>. Liver function testing and lipase levels are within normal limits. A diagnostic ultrasound is ordered and pending. Which of the following findings on abdominal ultrasound would be most suggestive of an acalculous disease process?
questions.solution:
This hospitalized patient presents with right upper quadrant abdominal pain, a positive Murphy sign, and likely sepsis, which is concerning for acute acalculous cholecystitis. Acalculous cholecystitis is gallbladder inflammation that is not caused by gallstones. It results from gallbladder stasis and ischemia that leads to inflammation. Acalculous cholecystitis is typically seen in patients who are hospitalized and critically ill.

When acute acalculous cholecystitis is suspected, patients should have laboratory testing, which should include CBC, ALP, GGT, CMP, AST, ALT, total bilirubin, ESR, CRP, lactate, amylase, and lipase levels. Diagnostic ultrasound should be performed. The presence of gallbladder wall thickening, sonographic Murphy sign, and cholecystic fluid indicates acute cholecystitis. If no gallstones are seen and/or echogenic bile or sludge is seen, then acalculous cholecystitis can be diagnosed. If there is uncertainty, CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis or a HIDA scan can be performed.  

Option Analysis

✅ Echogenic bile:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Gallbladder wall thickening (>3.5mm):
Incorrect: Gallbladder wall thickening is found in patients with both calculous and acalculous cholecystitis and is a diagnostic feature of acute cholecystitis despite the cause.  
❌ Pericholecystic fluid:
Incorrect: Pericholecystic fluid is found in patients with both calculous and acalculous cholecystitis and is a diagnostic feature of acute cholecystitis despite the cause.  
❌ Dilated common bile duct:
Incorrect: A dilated common bile duct is not suggestive of acute cholecystitis but, rather, reflects a hepatobiliary process such as choledocholithiasis or acute cholangitis.  
❌ Sonographic Murphy sign:
Incorrect: Sonographic Murphy sign (i.e. pain elicited when the sonographer presses directly over the gallbladder with the ultrasound probe) is found in patients with both calculous and acalculous cholecystitis and is a diagnostic feature of acute cholecystitis despite the cause.

questions.text: A 76-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of abdominal pain. The patient reports right upper abdominal pain for the past 2-3 days that radiates to his shoulder blade. Today he was feeling significantly worse and told his wife to bring him to the emergency department. Temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), blood pressure is 95/73 mmHg, pulse is 121/min, and SpO<sub>2</sub> is 99% on room air. Physical examination reveals diffuse abdominal tenderness and guarding. The patient is provided with intravenous fluids and empiric antibiotics. Laboratory results demonstrate leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 24,100 /mm<sup>3</sup>. An abdominal ultrasound is performed and demonstrates pericholecystic fluid, thickened gallbladder wall, and evidence of perforation. Which of the following is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of right upper abdominal pain and is ultimately found to have evidence of acute cholecystitis complicated by gallbladder perforation. This patient should have an emergency cholecystectomy for this potentially life-threatening complication. Other complications that require emergent cholecystectomy are gallbladder gangrene, abscess, and necrosis.

Stable patients with suspected acute cholecystitis should undergo diagnostic abdominal ultrasonography, which will typically identify the disease based on the presence of pericholecystic fluid, gallbladder wall thickening, or a positive Murphy sign. Stable patients with uncomplicated calculous cholecystitis should receive continued supportive care and be monitored for worsening response (e.g. continued pain and fever, worsening leukocytosis). Those that respond well and are good surgical candidates can be scheduled for  cholecystectomy, while those with poor response should have urgent surgical consultation for cholecystectomy. Patients with acalculous cholecystitis should also receive supportive care and be considered for cholecystectomy or percutaneous drainage via interventional radiology if they are not good surgical candidates.  

Option Analysis

✅ Emergent cholecystectomy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Supportive care and scheduled cholecystectomy:
Incorrect: This patient presents with findings of gallbladder perforation which is a life-threatening complication of acute cholecystitis that requires emergent cholecystectomy.  
❌ HIDA scan:
Incorrect: A HIDA scan is indicated for patients with suspected cholecystitis when a diagnostic ultrasound or CT of the abdomen and pelvis is inconclusive.  
❌ Endoscopic retrograde cholangiography:
Incorrect: Endoscopic retrograde cholangiography (ERCP) can be used to treat gallstones in the bile duct. But it is not appropriate treatment for acute cholecystitis complicated by gallbladder perforation.  
❌ Serial abdominal exams:
Incorrect: This patient presents with findings of gallbladder perforation, sepsis, and hemodynamic instability. He should have an emergent cholecystectomy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic with three days of right upper quadrant abdominal pain and fever. The patient has previously had three to four episodes of right upper quadrant pain, occasionally with vomiting, that were worse after eating and resolved within two to three hours. Vital signs include temperature of 38.6 ºC (101.5 ºF), heart rate of 108/min, blood pressure of 140/75 mmHg, respiratory rate of 18/min, and SpO2 of 100% on room air. The patient is sent to the emergency department for bloodwork and imaging. Bloodwork shows leukocytosis. Which of the following findings on physical exam would be most suggestive of the underlying diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient has a history of three to four episodes of biliary colic, usually described as intense right upper quadrant abdominal pain that is typically constant and caused by gallstones. The pain typically occurs when the biliary duct contracts on an impacted gallstone–often set off by eating, especially fatty foods, with increased pressure within the gallbladder. Patients often report associated nausea and vomiting.  

Acute cholecystitis presenting as fever, right upper quadrant pain, and leukocytosis can develop as a complication of gallstones from gallbladder inflammation. Physical examination will show right upper quadrant tenderness to palpation or epigastric tenderness. A positive Murphy sign is highly suggestive of acute cholecystitis. It is tested for by palpating the gallbladder during deep inspiration and is considered positive if the pain significantly worsens or if the patient stops inspiring because of the pain.



Abdominal ultrasound should be performed when acute cholecystitis is suspected. The gallbladder will appear distended and thickened with surrounding edema and gallstones may be seen. Acute cholecystitis can be definitively diagnosed in the right clinical setting with demonstration of gallbladder wall thickening or edema on imaging, a sonographic Murphy sign, or failure of the gallbladder to fill during cholescintigraphy.

Option Analysis

✅ Positive Murphy sign:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Tenderness at McBurney point:
Incorrect: Tenderness at McBurney point, which is 1.5 to 2 inches from the anterior superior iliac spine on a straight line to the umbilicus, is indicative of acute appendicitis not acute cholecystitis.
❌ Positive Rovsing sign:
Incorrect: Pain elicited in the right lower quadrant while the examiner pushes on the left lower quadrant is a positive Rovsing sign. This is suggestive of acute appendicitis, not acute cholecystitis.
❌ Positive Courvoisier sign:
Incorrect: A positive Courvoisier sign is a palpable gallbladder in the presence of jaundice. This is most suggestive of pancreatic or gallbladder malignancy, not acute cholecystitis.
❌ Epigastric tenderness to palpation:
Incorrect: Both epigastric and right upper quadrant tenderness can be seen on physical exam in acute cholecystitis. However epigastric tenderness can also be seen in other conditions such as pancreatitis and peptic ulcer disease.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of abdominal pain and confusion for the past 24 hours. The pain is stabbing in character, worse in the upper abdomen, and is associated with nausea and non-bloody vomiting. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include metformin and atorvastatin. Family history is noncontributory. Temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 85/55 mmHg. Physical examination shows that the patient is oriented to the person but not to time and place. Mucous membranes are dry and capillary refill is delayed. Skin and sclera are icteric. Abdominal examination shows marked tenderness in the right upper quadrant and epigastric region without rebound tenderness or guarding. Laboratory results are shown below. Ultrasound of the abdomen is suggestive of an impacted gallstone. Which of the following is the most likely location of gallstone impaction due to this patient’s symptoms?  

 Laboratory features 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Hemoglobin  14.5 g/dL 
 Leukocyte count  150,000/mm3 
 Platelet count    230,000 mm3 
 Serum electrolytes  
 Sodium  137 mEq/L 
 Potassium  4.5 mEq/L 
 Chloride  106 mEq/L 
 Bicarbonate  17 mEq/L 
 Bilirubin   
 Total   2.8 mg/dL 
 Direct  2.2 mg/dL 
 Alanine aminotransferase (ALT, GPT  65 U/L 
 Aspartate aminotransferase (AST, GOT  30 U/L 
 Lipase  65 U/L
questions.solution:
This patient with fever, jaundice, and right upper quadrant pain (RUQ) (aka Charcot triad) most likely has ascending cholangitis, secondary to the gallstone impaction in the common bile duct (CBD). Confusion and hypotension (Reynold pentad) are also sometimes seen in severe cases.  

Gallstones can migrate from the gallbladder into the cystic duct where it can obstruct the bile outflow, causing biliary colic (intense, spasmodic pain located in the right hypochondrium) when the gallbladder contracts. The accumulation of bile can subsequently lead to the development of cholecystitis, which presents clinically as a positive Murphy’s sign, which is pain and discomfort on inspiration when the inflamed gallbladder comes into contact with the examiner's hand in the RUQ.  

Gallstone impaction at the CBD can lead to bacterial invasion of bile from the intestinal flora. This can lead to the development of ascending cholangitis, characterized by Charcot triad. Additionally, when impacted in the main pancreatic duct, it can cause pancreatitis (e.g., anorexia, malaise, and right upper quadrant pain).  

Finally, an enlarged and inflamed gallbladder can develop communications with adjacent viscera (cholecystoenteric fistula), most commonly between the gallbladder and the duodenum. The stone from here passes freely until it reaches the ileum. It is characterized by signs and symptoms of bowel obstruction.  



Option Analysis

❌ Ileum:
Incorrect: Gallstone ileus is a complication of long-standing cholelithiasis where the gallstone forms a cholecystoenteric fistula between the gallbladder and the adjoint gut (duodenum). The stone from here passes freely until it reaches the ileum (narrowest portion of the intestine). It is characterized by signs and symptoms of bowel obstruction (abdominal pain/distention, nausea/vomiting, high-pitched bowel sounds, and abdominal tenderness). This patient’s presentation is consistent with ascending cholangitis.  
✅ Common bile duct:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Main pancreatic duct:
Incorrect: Gallstones can migrate from the common bile duct and obstruct the main pancreatic duct, leading to pancreatitis, which is inflammation of the pancreas. Symptoms of pancreatitis include anorexia, malaise, and right upper quadrant pain. Serum lipase levels are usually elevated (unlike this patient). Charcot’s triad in this patient is suggestive of common bile duct obstruction.  
❌ Cystic duct:
Incorrect: Gallstones are usually located in the gallbladder but can migrate in the cystic duct, obstructing the bile’s way out of the gallbladder. When the gallbladder contracts, this further leads to biliary colic, which is an intense, spasmodic pain located in the right upper quadrant (RUQ) of the abdomen. The accumulation of bile can also lead to the inflammation and irritation of gallbladder (cholecystitis), presenting as Murphy’s sign (pain/tenderness in the RUQ sufficient to cause an abrupt halt in inspiration) on physical examination. Charcot’s triad in this patient is suggestive of common bile duct obstruction.  
❌ Duodenum:
Incorrect: The caliber of duodenum is typically sufficient to allow the passage of larger gallstones.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of abdominal pain. The pain started suddenly six hours ago after she had dinner at a barbeque at her friend’s place. The pain is continuous, sharp, radiates to the right scapula, and is 8/10 in severity. The patient reports similar abdominal pain of lesser severity in the past 2 months. The review of systems is significant for nausea and vomiting. Past medical history is noncontributory. BMI is 37 kg/2. Temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), pulse is 104/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg. Physical examination shows right upper quadrant tenderness with deep palpation. The rest of the examination is within normal limits. Laboratory investigation shows a leukocyte count of 12,000/mm3 and an elevated serum total bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase concentrations. An abdominal ultrasound reveals gallstones, thickened gallbladder wall with edema, and a normal common bile duct. Intravenous fluids are started. Which of the following is the best next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is consistent with acute cholecystitis (e.g., right upper quadrant pain and tenderness associated with nausea and vomiting with ultrasound evidence of thickened gallbladder wall with gallstones).  

Patients with uncomplicated cholecystitis should be managed with early (<72 hours) cholecystectomy. Other indications of cholecystectomy include:  

  •  Uncomplicated cholecystitis 
  •  Asymptomatic cholelithiasis in patients who are at increased risk for gallbladder carcinoma 
  •  Acalculous cholecystitis 
  •  Gallbladder polyps >0.5 cm 
  •  Porcelain gallbladder 
  •  Choledochoithiasis 
  •  Biliary pancreatitis 
Cholecystectomy can be performed either laparoscopically or via an open surgical technique. During the procedure, it is important to identify the Triangle of Calot (cystohepatic triangle) to avoid damage to the cystic duct and artery. The triangle is bounded by the cystic duct inferiorly, common hepatic duct medially, and the inferior surface of the liver superiorly. The cystic artery lies within the triangle and is used to locate it during a laparoscopic cholecystectomy. It may also contain anomalous sectoral bile ducts or an accessory right hepatic artery. Therefore, dissection in the triangle of Calot is ill-advised until the lateral-most structures have been cleared and identification of the cystic duct is definitive.  



The bile duct can also be damaged during a gallbladder removal, which causes leakage of bile into the abdomen, leading to peritonitis. Moreover, the surgical instruments used to remove the gallbladder can also injure surrounding structures, such as the bowel and blood vessels.

Option Analysis

❌ Urgent percutaneous gallbladder drainage:
Incorrect: Percutaneous cholecystostomy is an image-guided placement of a drainage catheter into the gallbladder lumen. It is usually indicated in complicated cholecystitis (e.g., emphysematous cholecystitis) or unexplained sepsis in critically ill patients.  
❌ Delayed cholecystectomy after hospitalization:
Incorrect: Early cholecystectomy within 72 hours reduces the duration of disease and hospitalization and reduces mortality as compared to delayed cholecystectomy.  
✅ Cholecystectomy within 72 hours:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hepatobiliary iminodiacetic acid scan:
Incorrect: The hepatobiliary iminodiacetic acid (HIDA) scan is indicated if the diagnosis of acute cholecystitis remains uncertain following ultrasonography. It uses a nuclear tracer that is excreted in bile. Failure to visualize the gallbladder suggests an obstruction. This patient’s ultrasound is suggestive of acute cholecystitis and, therefore, further imaging is not required.   
❌ Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography:
Incorrect: Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) is usually performed to evaluate for concurrent choledocholithiasis in patients with acute cholecystitis with elevations of liver transaminases, total bilirubin, or evidence of common bile duct dilatation on ultrasound. It is not indicated in this patient.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman presents to the emergency department to evaluate right upper quadrant abdominal pain. The patient has experienced recurrent episodes of right upper quadrant pain after eating. However, the current episode is more severe. The pain is 10 out of 10 in severity, radiates to the right shoulder, and is associated with nausea and vomiting. Past medical history is unremarkable. Temperature is 37.8°C (100°F), blood pressure is 132/89 mmHg, and pulse is 107/min. Physical examination reveals a positive Murphy sign, and bedside ultrasound demonstrates pericholecystic fluid. The patient is subsequently provided with intravenous fluids, antibiotics, and general surgery is consulted. Which of the following is the most appropriate analgesic treatment for this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with an acute surgical abdomen in the setting of cholecystitis. Patients with moderate-severe pain in the setting of an acute surgical abdomen are best treated with strong opiate agonists, such as morphine.    

The primary indication for opiate analgesics in the treatment of acute moderate-severe pain. Opiates have been well-known to provide analgesia in patients presenting with acute pain that is often refractory to other analgesic medications, such as acetaminophen or nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). Morphine, as the prototypical opiate agonist, is commonly administered intravenously, with desired effects peaking between 15-20 minutes and lasting for 2-4 hours.    

Fentanyl, another opiate agonist, has a much faster onset of action (1-2 minutes) with a duration of action of approximately 60 minutes. Due to these characteristics, fentanyl is more commonly used in acute trauma patients or those requiring frequent neurologic assessments.  

Hydromorphone is also becoming more widely used as an analgesic for acute pain management. This medication is more potent than fentanyl or morphine and is often used in patients with pain refractory to other opioid analgesics. 

Option Analysis

✅ Morphine :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Ketorolac :
Incorrect: Ketorolac is a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID). This patient has evidence of acute cholecystitis and will likely undergo cholecystectomy. Administration of an NSAID could worsen intraoperative bleeding.   
❌ Acetaminophen :
Incorrect: Acetaminophen provides analgesic relief for those with mild to moderate pain and is typically administered orally. Given the severity of this patient’s pain, administration of a stronger medication is warranted.   
❌ Tramadol :
Incorrect: Tramadol functions as a weak opioid agonist and also inhibits the reuptake of norepinephrine and serotonin. Given the severity of this patient’s pain, the administration of a stronger opiate agonist is warranted.   
❌ Oxycodone :
Incorrect: Oxycodone is an opiate agonist administered orally. Given this patient has acute cholecystitis and will likely undergo surgery, she should not take any medications by mouth.

questions.text: A 53-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of cramping abdominal pain, and yellow skin.
