❌ Admission to the intensive care unit for supportive care and early enteral feeding:
Incorrect: While early enteral feeding is indicated in the management of acute pancreatitis, providing supportive care and early enteral feeding without addressing the underlying biliary obstruction would not be sufficient and could worsen this patient's condition.

CT imaging with pancreatic protocol demonstrates a well-defined 2 cm solid mass in the head of the pancreas that is hypervascular during the arterial phase and is not associated with biliary ductal dilation. Which of the following patients is most likely to have these laboratory and imaging findings?

choices.text: A 54-year-old man who presents with abdominal pain, diarrhea, and refractory gastroesophageal reflux symptoms despite maximal proton pump-inhibitor therapy
A 48-year-old man with alcohol use disorder and an episode of acute pancreatitis six weeks ago who-presents with abdominal pain
A 75-year-old woman with a 30-pack-year smoking history who presents with weight loss and jaundice
A 33-year-old woman with no past medical history who recently underwent cross-sectional imaging following a motor vehicle accident
A 67-year-old man with type 2 diabetes mellitus who presents with increased insulin requirements, diarrhea, and an erythematous rash

questions.solution:
This patient has normal transaminases, normal CEA and CA 19-9, and a well-defined solid pancreatic mass in the head of the pancreas that is hypervascular on the arterial phase, which is consistent with a pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor (PNET). Two types of PNETs are typically found in the pancreatic head: gastrinoma and somatostatinoma. This patient also has blood work showing anemia and positive fecal occult blood which could be consistent with a peptic ulcer. The patient described in (A) also has diarrhea and resistant GERD.  Diarrhea and severe acid-related peptic disease can be seen with Zollinger-Ellison (ZES) syndrome, which is associated with gastrinoma.

A thorough history and physical are essential when assessing a patient with a pancreatic lesion, as the presentations of different pancreatic lesions can vary significantly. In a patient with a solid pancreatic lesion on cross-sectional imaging, the differential diagnosis includes pancreatic adenocarcinoma, pancreatic adenoma, and PNET. Pancreatic adenocarcinoma is often associated with weight loss. If it is located in the pancreatic head, it can obstruct the common bile duct, resulting in biliary ductal dilation with jaundice and elevated transaminases. Pancreatic adenomas are typically asymptomatic unless they are large enough to cause mass effect. PNETs can be either functional or nonfunctional, and when they are functional they cause symptoms due to the hormones they secrete.

The most common type of PNET is insulinoma, characterized by the Whipple Triad (symptoms of hypoglycemia which resolve with glucose administration, and plasma glucose ≤55 mg/dL during symptomatic episodes). The second most common PNET is gastrinoma, which can cause Zollinger-Ellison syndrome. Other rare PNETs include VIPomas, which can cause watery diarrhea, hypoglycemia, and achlorhydria; glucagonomas, which can cause new-onset diabetes mellitus; and somatostatinomas, which can cause gallstones.  

Option Analysis

✅ A 54-year-old man who presents with abdominal pain, diarrhea, and refractory gastroesophageal reflux symptoms despite maximal proton pump-inhibitor therapy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ A 48-year-old man with alcohol use disorder and an episode of acute pancreatitis six weeks ago who-presents with abdominal pain:
Incorrect: This presentation is most consistent with a pancreatic pseudocyst which would not cause anemia and would not appear as a solid lesion on cross-sectional imaging. A pancreatic pseudocyst would instead appear as a well-encapsulated cystic mass adjacent to the pancreas.  
❌ A 75-year-old woman with a 30-pack-year smoking history who presents with weight loss and jaundice:
Incorrect: This presentation is most consistent with pancreatic adenocarcinoma, which is accompanied by elevated transaminases and elevated tumor markers (i.e. CA 19-9, CEA). Cross-sectional imaging would demonstrate an ill-defined mass in the head of the pancreas with associated biliary ductal dilation.  
❌ A 33-year-old woman with no past medical history who recently underwent cross-sectional imaging following a motor vehicle accident  :
Incorrect: A young healthy patient with an asymptomatic, incidentally identified pancreatic lesion likely has either a pancreatic adenoma or a non-neoplastic pancreatic cyst. Although a pancreatic adenoma could appear as a well-defined mass in the head of the pancreas, it would not cause anemia and melena.  
❌ A 67-year-old man with type 2 diabetes mellitus who presents with increased insulin requirements, diarrhea, and an erythematous rash:
Incorrect: This presentation is most consistent with glucagonoma. These tumors are typically located in the tail of the pancreas, not the head, and are not associated with anemia or melena.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman with a past medical history of gallstones presents to the emergency department with constant epigastric pain that radiates to the back with associated nausea and vomiting. She underwent an endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) procedure 36 hours ago to remove a biliary stone. The patient has a 30-pack-year smoking history. BMI is 28 kg/m2. Temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), blood pressure is 105/68 mmHg, pulse is 92/min, respiratory rate is 20 per minute, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. The patient appears uncomfortable. The abdomen is tender in the epigastrium with guarding. Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. Laboratory evaluation at admission shows the following findings listed below. CT scan of the abdomen reveals peripancreatic free fluid, fat stranding, and pancreatic edema. Which of the following factors is most indicative of a poor prognosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with severe epigastric pain radiating to the back, nausea, vomiting, and elevated pancreatic enzymes after an ERCP. This clinical presentation is consistent with the diagnosis of post-ERCP acute pancreatitis. The most important prognostic factor in this patient is the WBC >16,000/mm³ on admission, which may indicate systemic inflammatory response syndrome and is included in Ranson Criteria as an indicator of poor prognosis.

The diagnosis of acute pancreatitis is typically made based on the presence of two out of three criteria:
 
  1.  Acute onset of persistent, severe epigastric pain often radiating to the back 
  2.  Serum lipase or amylase >3 times the upper limit of normal 
  3.  Characteristic findings on abdominal imaging  
Severity of acute pancreatitis can be classified as mild to moderate (absence of organ failure or complication, or only transient organ failure), and severe (persistent organ failure, or severe complications).

In the context of acute pancreatitis, severity is gauged based on the presence of organ failure or complications. Organ failure can be seen with abnormal lab values such as elevated liver function tests (LFTs), indicating hepatitis, or an elevated creatinine level, indicative of acute kidney injury. Complications from pancreatitis include pancreatic pseudocyst or necrosis, peripancreatic splanchnic venous thrombosis, or abdominal compartment syndrome.

There are various assessment scores that help predict the severity or mortality in acute pancreatitis. The Revised Atlanta classification is one such tool, which stratifies acute pancreatitis into interstitial edematous pancreatitis, a less severe form, and necrotizing pancreatitis, which is more severe. The Ranson criteria is another commonly used assessment that predicts mortality in acute pancreatitis. This scoring system encompasses 11 prognostic signs, with the first 5 assessed upon hospital admission.
 

Option Analysis

✅ WBC of 17,000/mm³:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Post-ERCP pancreatitis:
Incorrect: Pancreatitis is a common complication of ERCP. However, it does not necessarily indicate a poor prognosis and does not correlate well with disease severity.  
❌ BMI >25 kg/m2:
Incorrect: Obesity, defined as a BMI of >30 kg/m2, is associated with an increased risk of severe pancreatitis, however a BMI of >25 kg/m2 alone does not indicate a poor prognosis.  
❌ Serum amylase >2000 U/L:
Incorrect: Elevated amylase and lipase are characteristic of acute pancreatitis, but the level of these enzymes does not correlate well with disease severity or prognosis.  
❌ Patient age of 43 years:
Incorrect: Age >55 years is associated with a higher risk of complications and mortality in acute pancreatitis.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of multiple episodes of non-bloody vomiting and severe upper abdominal pain that began earlier in the day. He describes the pain as constant. It is localized to the epigastric region and radiates to the back. He has not had diarrhea, chest pain, or changes in bowel habits. He has no history of similar symptoms, there is no history of recent trauma, and he does not take any regular medications. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), blood pressure is 105/70 mmHg, heart rate is 110 beats per minute, respiratory rate is 22 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical examination reveals tenderness to palpation in the epigastrium without rebound or guarding. Bowel sounds are decreased. Laboratory results are shown below. Considering the most likely diagnosis, which of the following historical features is most likely to be present?

 Laboratory test Result
 White blood cell count 14,000/mm³
 Serum amylase 460 U/L
 Serum lipase 720 U/L
 ALT 35 U/L
 AST 30 U/L
 ALP 90 U/L
 Total bilirubin 0.8 mg/dL

choices.text: Family history of inflammatory bowel disease
Long-term use of proton pump inhibitors

questions.solution:
This patient presents with vomiting, severe epigastric pain radiating to the back, and elevated serum amylase and lipase. The most likely diagnosis is acute pancreatitis. The most common causes of acute pancreatitis are gallstones and alcohol consumption. Because the absence of jaundice, significantly elevated liver enzymes, or biliary colic makes gallstone pancreatitis less likely, recent heavy alcohol consumption is the most likely contributing factor in this patient. Alcohol damages the pancreas, leading to inflammation and acute pancreatitis.

Key historical elements to obtain when evaluating a patient with vomiting include the onset, duration, and characteristics of vomiting, associated symptoms (e.g., abdominal pain, fever, or headache), recent dietary intake, medication use, and relevant medical history, such as alcohol use or pregnancy. Physical exam should focus on assessing for signs of dehydration. Findings of abdominal tenderness, distention, and rebound or guarding suggest gastrointestinal causes. Patients should also be assessed for neurologic findings like altered mental status or focal deficits that suggest increased intracranial pressure and a central nervous system cause. Life-threatening conditions such as bowel obstruction or intracranial hemorrhage should be differentiated from less critical etiologies like gastroenteritis and medication side effects.   

Option Analysis

❌ Family history of inflammatory bowel disease:
Incorrect: This patient with vomiting, epigastric pain radiating to the back, and elevated lipase and amylase most likely has pancreatitis and not inflammatory bowel disease.  
✅ Recent heavy alcohol consumption:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Long-term use of proton pump inhibitors:
Incorrect: Proton pump inhibitors are not associated with pancreatitis.
❌ Recent consumption of undercooked chicken:
Incorrect: Undercooked chicken can lead to gastrointestinal infections like Campylobacter and salmonella; however, such infections typically present with diarrhea and fever rather than vomiting and epigastric pain.
❌ Chronic non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) use:
Incorrect: Chronic NSAID use is associated with gastritis and peptic ulcer disease, not acute pancreatitis.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of abdominal pain radiating to the back, nausea, and vomiting over the past 6 hours. Past medical history is unremarkable. The patient has a history of alcohol use disorder. Temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F), blood pressure is 92/65 mmHg, pulse is 126/min, respiratory rate is 24/min, and oxygen saturation is 94% on room air. The patient appears uncomfortable. Abdominal examination reveals distension and tenderness to palpation in the epigastrium. Periumbilical ecchymosis is present. Pulmonary examination is significant for bilateral rales at the lung bases. Laboratory evaluation demonstrates a WBC count of 15,000/mm<sup>3</sup>, amylase of 2300 U/L, and lipase of 1800 U/L. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
This patient presents with abdominal pain radiating to the back and elevated amylase and lipase, consistent with a diagnosis of acute pancreatitis. This patient’s physical examination findings, including fever, tachycardia, tachypnea, hypotension, bilateral crackles, and periumbilical ecchymosis (Cullen sign), suggest severe acute pancreatitis complicated by systemic inflammatory response syndrome. Acute pancreatitis is characterized by inflammation and autodigestion of the pancreas, which results in substantial hypovolemia. The initial management of acute pancreatitis includes aggressive fluid resuscitation, pain control, and nutritional support.

Fluid resuscitation is aimed at improving organ perfusion and minimizing the risk of end-organ damage. Pain management is another crucial component of acute pancreatitis care. Adequate analgesia improves patient comfort and reduces the physiological stress response. Early enteral feeding is encouraged to maintain the integrity of the gut mucosa and reduce bacterial translocation. The underlying cause of pancreatitis, such as gallstones or alcohol use, should be identified and addressed to prevent recurrence of the disease.  

Option Analysis

✅ Administration of IV lactate ringer:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis:
Incorrect: CT is indicated to evaluate for complications of pancreatitis such as necrosis, or pseudocyst formation. However it is not necessary to make the diagnosis of pancreatitis in this patient with epigastric pain radiating to the back and severely elevated lipase and amylase. IV fluid resuscitation should take precedence over obtaining a CT scan.  
❌ Administration of IV piperacillin-tazobactam:
Incorrect: Routine use of prophylactic antibiotics in acute pancreatitis is not recommended. Antibiotics should be reserved for patients with evidence of infected necrosis or extra-pancreatic complications.  
❌ Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP):
Incorrect: ERCP is indicated within 24 hours of presentation if there is evidence of acute pancreatitis with concurrent acute cholangitis. Stabilizing the patient takes precedence.  
❌ Administration of intravenous morphine:
Incorrect: While pain management is a crucial aspect of treating acute pancreatitis, it is not the first step. Aggressive fluid resuscitation remains the initial priority.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of abdominal cramps, bloating, and diarrhea. The symptoms began several weeks ago. He describes the diarrhea as “greasy and difficult to flush.” He has unintentionally lost 13-lb over this time period and has also felt significantly more fatigued. The patient has not had any recent rashes, joint pains, or blood in the diarrhea. He has been sexually active with 3 partners over the past year and uses condoms inconsistently. Past medical history is noncontributory. He lives in the Dominican Republic. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 122/84 mmHg. Physical examination reveals conjunctival pallor. Mild abdominal tenderness is elicited with palpation, and bowel sounds are hyperactive. Fecal occult blood test is negative, and stool microscopy shows no parasites or leukocytes. Laboratory testing reveals the following findings:  
 
 Anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies (IgA, IgG)  Negative 
 Anti-endomysial antibody (IgA)  Negative 
 Deamidated gliadin peptide (IgG)  Negative 
 HIV-1/2 PCR  Negative  

Upper endoscopy reveals flattening of the duodenal folds. Biopsy of the small intestine shows blunted villi and elongated crypts with increased inflammatory cells. A peripheral blood smear shows hypersegmented neutrophils. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?

choices.text: Avoidance of gluten in the diet
Avoidance of lactose in the diet

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with symptoms of malabsorption and steatorrhea, which has likely contributed to his signs of megaloblastic anemia (e.g., fatigue, hypersegmented neutrophils). Taking into consideration his past history of living in the Caribbean and endoscopic findings of flattened intestinal folds, he likely has tropical sprue.   

Tropical sprue commonly affects individuals living in tropical environments (e.g., Haiti, Dominican Republic, Puerto Rico), as well as travelers returning from these areas. The condition is likely caused by toxins and fermentation products produced by bacterial overgrowth, which can cause significant small bowel structural damage. Biopsy would show findings that are remarkably similar to celiac disease, such as the atrophic villi and crypt hyperplasia.   

Due to nutritional malabsorption, patients with tropical sprue may have impaired B12 and folate absorption in the small intestine, which can lead to megaloblastic anemia. Patients can also have impaired absorption of fat-soluble vitamins (vitamins A, D, E, K). Since the underlying cause is bacterial overgrowth, treatment consists of antibiotics (e.g. doxycycline), as well as folate supplementation.   



Option Analysis

✅ Antibiotics and folate supplementation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Avoidance of gluten in the diet:
Incorrect: Gluten-free diets are essential in the management of patients with celiac disease. Although celiac disease may cause bloating and diarrhea, it more commonly manifests in individuals of Northern European descent. Furthermore, patients with celiac disease would typically be positive for anti-tissue transglutaminase, anti-endomysial, or anti-deamidated gliadin peptide antibodies.
❌ Avoidance of lactose in the diet:
Incorrect: Lactose intolerance is best managed by avoiding lactose-containing foods. Patients commonly present with bloating and diarrhea. Diagnostic studies would show a positive hydrogen breath test, due to bacterial fermentation of undigested lactose in the intestinal tract, as well as normal endoscopic findings, since there is no structural damage. This patient’s endoscopic findings make lactose intolerance an unlikely diagnosis. 
❌ Highly active antiretroviral therapy:
Incorrect: Highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART) is extremely effective in the treatment of HIV. Although HIV may also present with chronic diarrhea, this patient’s negative HIV 1/2 PCR test makes this diagnosis unlikely. 
❌ Mesalamine:
Incorrect: Mesalamine is effective in the treatment of inflammatory bowel diseases, such as Crohn disease and ulcerative colitis. Although these conditions can also present with diarrhea, their endoscopic findings would differ from this patient’s. Crohn disease would show sporadic granulomatous inflammation, whereas ulcerative colitis would show continuous lesions at the rectum.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of diarrhea and abdominal cramping. The patient reports 4 episodes of watery diarrhea and non-bilious, non-bloody emesis throughout the night. The patient reports that he was able to drink water this morning and keep it down, but he continues to have watery diarrhea and is concerned about dehydration. The patient is otherwise healthy and does not take any daily medications. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), blood pressure is 138/91 mmHg, pulse is 94/min, respiratory rate is 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical examination demonstrates mildly dry mucous membranes, and abdominal examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Administration of 1 L normal saline intravenously

questions.solution:
This patient presents with uncomplicated gastroenteritis. Given that he is able to tolerate oral intake, the best next step in management is to allow a trial of oral rehydration therapy.
 

Gastroenteritis refers to inflammation of the gastrointestinal tract, typically caused by infectious pathogens. These pathogens injure the intestinal lining, leading to fluid shifts and water loss through diarrhea and emesis. Patients with gastroenteritis should be asked whether the diarrhea is watery or bloody. Stool cultures may be sent to identify common pathogens which can include bacteria, viruses, or parasites.

The acute management of gastroenteritis begins with assessing for hemodynamic stability.  Patients who have evidence of significant dehydration should be provided with proper volume resuscitation. Acute management of stable patients involves obtaining a focused history and physical assessment to determine the type of gastroenteritis (e.g. bloody vs. watery), potential complicating factors (e.g. immunosuppression), and the potential pathogens involved.

In general, patients with evidence of mild dehydration who are able to tolerate oral intake should have a trial of oral rehydration therapy. If they continue to tolerate oral intake and improve, then no further work-up or management is indicated, as most cases of mild gastroenteritis will resolve without any other treatment. In contrast, patients with evidence of moderate-to-severe dehydration and patients with ongoing fluid losses who are unable to tolerate oral fluids require intravenous fluids, as well as further work-up and consideration of empiric antibiotic therapy.

Option Analysis

✅ Oral rehydration therapy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Administration of 1 L normal saline intravenously:
Incorrect: This patient has proven that he is able to tolerate oral rehydration and has evidence of only mild dehydration; therefore he should have oral rehydration therapy.  
❌ Administration of piperacillin-tazobactam:
Incorrect: This patient likely has uncomplicated gastroenteritis and requires symptomatic care with oral rehydration. Administration of broad-spectrum antibiotics may be indicated in the setting of diarrhea in a patient who is severely ill or immunocompromised.  
❌ Transabdominal ultrasonography:
Incorrect: Transabdominal ultrasonography is likely to be of little diagnostic utility in this patient with uncomplicated gastroenteritis.  
❌ Stool culture:
Incorrect: This patient has mild uncomplicated gastroenteritis which is typically self-limited. He can be treated with oral rehydration therapy and, if needed, bismuth subsalicylate and an antimotility agent. He can be reassessed if he is not improving.

questions.text: A 76-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for evaluation of bloody diarrhea. The patient reports 8 episodes per day of bloody, mucoid diarrhea, as well as associated abdominal cramping and tenesmus. The patient is otherwise healthy and does not take any daily medications. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), blood pressure is 105/71, pulse is 115/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical examination demonstrates dry mucous membranes and decreased skin turgor. Rectal examination is positive for hemoccult blood. The patient is started on intravenous fluids. Stool cultures are obtained and pending. Which of the following pathogens is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with mucoid stools and bloody diarrhea which are findings that can be seen with infectious gastroenteritis. Pathogens associated with bloody diarrhea include Campylobacter jejuni, Shigella dysenteriae, Salmonella enterica, Yersinia enterocolitica, enteroinvasive and enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli, and Entamoeba histolytica. Campylobacter jejuni can cause a diarrheal illness associated with up to 10 unformed stools a day and bloody diarrhea. There can be a prodrome characterized by high fever with rigors, generalized achiness, dizziness, and delirium. The infection is typically self-limited.

Gastroenteritis can be classified as causing watery or bloody diarrhea. It may be caused by bacteria, viruses, or parasites. Watery diarrhea can be caused by Staphylococcus aureus, Bacillus cereus, Enterovirus, Norovirus, Adenovirus, enterotoxigenic E. Coli(most common cause of travelers’ diarrhea), enteropathogenic E. Coli or EPEC, as well as Cryptosporidium and Giardia. All patients with diarrhea should be questioned about sick contacts, recent food intake, recent travel, outdoor activities, living abroad, work in daycare or school settings, medications, recent antibiotic use, and recent hospitalizations.  

Option Analysis

✅ Campylobacter jejuni:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli:
Incorrect: Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli is the most common cause of traveler’s diarrhea, which typically presents with watery non-bloody diarrhea.  
❌ Staphylococcus aureus:
Incorrect: Staphylococcus aureus is a common cause of food-borne gastroenteritis. Patients  typically presents with watery diarrhea, as opposed to bloody and mucoid diarrhea.  
❌ Giardia lamblia:
Incorrect: Giardia lamblia is commonly acquired via consumption of unfiltered drinking water while camping or performing outdoor activities. It typically presents with watery diarrhea and/or fatty diarrhea (also called steatorrhea) due to malabsorption and not bloody mucoid diarrhea.  
❌ Norovirus:
Incorrect: Norovirus is a common cause of watery diarrhea. It is often acquired aboard cruise ships or in daycare facilities.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents to the gastroenterology clinic for follow-up of chronic hepatitis C. Four weeks ago, the patient was diagnosed with chronic hepatitis C infection and was started on sofosbuvir-velpatasvir. The patient has no significant past medical history and takes no medications. He drinks a few beers during the week and 5-6 beers on the weekends. AST, ALT, and total bilirubin were mildly elevated at that time. On today’s visit, the patient is feeling well and has more energy since starting treatment. Temperature is 37.0 ºC (98.6 ºF), pulse is 78/min, blood pressure is 110/71 mmHg, respiratory rate is 12/min, and SpO<sub>2</sub> is 100% on room air. Repeat AST, ALT, and total bilirubin levels have significantly improved. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Perform CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
This patient with chronic hepatitis C infection is responding well to recently started antiviral treatment based on improving symptoms and laboratory studies.

Hepatitis C virus (HCV) is transmitted via contaminated blood or sexual contact and can cause an asymptomatic acute infection. If the infection is not cleared, it can lead to chronic infection, which predisposes the patient to cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma. Hepatitis C should be suspected in patients with known high-risk behaviors or exposures (e.g., tattooing with non-sterile equipment, IV drug use, sexual contact with a known HCV carrier). When HCV is suspected, serum HCV antibody testing should be performed. If positive, serum HCV RNA should then be tested to determine if the patient has an active infection with a positive viral load.
 
Patients with active infection (positive HCV RNA) should be treated with antivirals, such as sofosbuvir-velpatasvir or glecaprevir-pibrentasvir, and screened for viral co-infections, like hepatitis B and HIV. Patients should also be counseled about lifestyle modifications (e.g. alcohol cessation) and vaccinated against hepatitis A and B virus. CBC, creatinine, AST, ALT, bilirubin, and INR should be monitored serially to ensure improvement. Serial ultrasounds can be performed as well, and alpha-fetoprotein testing is sometimes performed if cirrhosis is present. After 12 weeks of therapy, HCV RNA testing should be repeated to assess the virologic response to treatment.  

Option Analysis

✅ Provide alcohol cessation counseling:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Check serum HCV RNA:
Incorrect: This is indicated after 12 weeks of therapy to confirm resolution of hepatitis C virus. This test is not necessary at this point as it has only been four weeks.  
❌ Check serum GGT:
Incorrect: This test can help confirm hepatobiliary pathology in patients where it is unclear whether an elevated alkaline phosphatase is from bone or hepatobiliary pathology. It would not be useful in this case.  
❌ Perform CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis:
Incorrect: Serial imaging can be performed in patients with known or suspected cirrhosis. Ultrasonography would be more appropriate in this case, given the low cost and lack of radiation exposure.  
❌ Vaccinate against hepatitis D virus:
Incorrect: Patients with hepatitis C virus infection should be vaccinated against hepatitis A and hepatitis B viruses. There is no vaccination for hepatitis D.

He has not experienced abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, or fatigue. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus. Current medications include lisinopril, metformin, glyburide, and aspirin. He drinks alcohol socially and has a 30-pack-year smoking history. The patient also has a history of intravenous drug use and was undomiciled in his early 30s. questions.solution:
This patient has elevated liver enzymes and hepatitis C virus (HCV) IgG titers, and high HCV RNA levels. These findings are consistent with HCV infection, and the patient is started on interferon-alpha (IFN-α) therapy.

Interferons (IFNs) are cytokines that exhibit a broad spectrum of antiviral activities and immunomodulating and antiproliferative properties. Currently, only two types of interferons are available for clinical use: IFNα2A and IFNα2B.

The selective antiviral action of IFN-α is primarily due to its ability to activate host cell ribonucleases that preferentially degrade viral mRNA. IFN-α also promotes the formation of natural killer cells that destroy liver cells infected by HCV. It is usually given either as an intramuscular or subcutaneous injection. Sometimes INFs can be provided in pegylated IFN (i.e. IFN plus polyethylene glycol).

IFNs are used in the treatment of both chronic HBV and HCV infections. When treating HCV infection, IFNs are used either as monotherapy or in combination with other antiviral medications such as ribavirin. Other indications include herpes virus infection, papillomavirus infection, and Kaposi sarcoma occurring in the setting of HIV infection.

Side effects of IFN-α include flu-like symptoms (e.g., fever, malaise, nausea, vomiting), bone marrow suppression leading to neutropenia and thrombocytopenia, neurotoxicity (e.g., sleepiness, depression, behavioral disturbances), and liver dysfunction leading to elevated liver enzymes. It can also cause alopecia, which is more common in children.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Activation of host cell ribonuclease:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Inhibition of viral protease activity:
Incorrect: Protease inhibitors are drugs that inhibit the action of HIV-1 protease, an enzyme that cleaves precursor proteins into smaller fragments. These fragments are needed for viral growth, infectivity, and replication. Examples of protease inhibitors include ritonavir and indinavir.  
❌ Inhibition of virion release from infected cells:
Incorrect: Neuraminidase inhibitors (NAIs) are a class of medication that can treat influenza infection by preventing viral progeny release from the host cells. Examples of NAIs include zanamivir and oseltamivir.  
❌ Prevention of viral entry into the target cell:
Incorrect: Enfuvirtide blocks the action of viral fusion proteins and prevents the virus from entering the target cell. It is an antiretroviral agent used in the management of HIV infection. In contrast, this patient’s presentation is more consistent with hepatitis C virus infection.  
❌ Inhibition of viral DNA replication:
Incorrect: Hepatitis B medications, including nucleoside analogs (e.g., entecavir, lamivudine) and nucleotide analogs (e.g., adefovir, tenofovir), are incorporated into growing viral DNA strands. Once these analogs have been incorporated, no additional nucleotides can be added, and DNA synthesis stops. Interferon-ɑ, however, works via a different mechanism of action.

The patient received a blood transfusion several decades ago following complicated childbirth. She does not use tobacco, alcohol, or recreational drugs. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg. Physical examination is unremarkable. Laboratory results are shown below. questions.solution:
This patient presents with fatigue, dull abdominal pain, elevated hepatitis C virus (HCV) IgG titers, and high HCV RNA levels. These findings are consistent with HCV infection. The patient is started on sofosbuvir and daclatasvir.

Daclatasvir is an NS5A inhibitor often used in combination with sofosbuvir to treat HCV infection. NS5A is a membrane-associated phosphoprotein part of the HCV RNA replication complex and is essential for viral replication and assembly. Inhibition of this phosphoprotein prevents HCV RNA replication. Other NS5A inhibitors include elbasvir, ledipasvir, ombitasvir, and velpatasvir.

Side effects associated with NS5A inhibitor use include mild to moderate headache, fatigue, and gastrointestinal irritation. Daclatasvir is primarily metabolized through CYP3A metabolism and should not be given strong inducers or inhibitors of this enzyme.  

Option Analysis

❌ Viral DNA polymerase:
Incorrect: Hepatitis medications, including nucleoside analogs (e.g., entecavir, lamivudine) and nucleotide analogs (e.g., adefovir, tenofovir), are incorporated into growing viral DNA and RNA strands. Once these analogs have been incorporated, viral polymerase, and the synthesis of genetic material stops, no additional nucleotides can be added. In contrast, daclatasvir works via a different mechanism of action.  
✅ HCV-encoded proteins:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Inosine monophosphate dehydrogenase:
Incorrect: Ribavirin is an antiviral medication that inhibits viral production of guanine nucleotides through competitive inhibition of inosine monophosphate (IMP) dehydrogenase. It is usually used as an adjunct to interferon therapy.  
❌ Virion release from infected cells:
Incorrect: Neuraminidase inhibitors (NAIs) are a class of medication that blocks the enzyme neuraminidase. NAIs can be used to treat influenza infection by preventing viral progeny release from the host cells. Examples of NAIs include zanamivir and oseltamivir.  
❌ Viral entry into the target cell:
Incorrect: Enfuvirtide blocks the action of viral fusion proteins and prevents the virus from entering the target cell. It is an antiretroviral agent used in the management of HIV infection. In contrast, this patient’s presentation is more consistent with hepatitis C virus infection.

This patient’s screening Hepatitis B labs are consistent with chronic hepatitis B infection. He should be treated with antiviral therapy given his age, family history of hepatocellular carcinoma, high viral load with active replication, and plans to start immunosuppressing medication.  Patients with chronic hepatitis B should also have a hepatic elastography to assess for fibrosis unless liver biopsy is indicated.

Treatment of hepatitis B infection varies depending on the stage and presenting features of the disease.  Treatment may be purely supportive in mild cases, and in more severe cases treatment may include medications or even liver transplantation.

The need for antiviral medication in chronic hepatitis B infection is determined by assessment of viral load using HBV DNA, viral replication, and hepatitis e antigen and antibody status along with consideration of patient-specific risk factors and the condition of the liver.  High levels of HBV DNA, active viral replication, elevated ALT, family history of hepatocellular carcinoma, age over 40, pregnancy, acute liver failure, presence of cirrhosis, immunosuppression, and coinfection with hepatitis C or HIV are all indications for treatment with antiviral therapy.

When indicated, first-line treatment is with nucleoside inhibitors such as entecavir or tenofovir.  Pegylated interferon alpha may also be considered in the treatment of chronic hepatitis B.  Benefits of therapy include viral suppression, reduced risk of recurrent HBV if a liver transplant is needed, reduced risk of hepatocellular carcinoma, and decreased risk of developing cirrhosis.

Long-term management of chronic hepatitis B should include regular laboratory monitoring of CBC, CMP, PT/INR, hepatitis B DNA, and e antigen as well as routine surveillance for hepatocellular carcinoma with liver ultrasound and measurement of alpha-fetoprotein. Hepatic elastography should be done in all patients to assess for fibrosis unless a liver biopsy is needed.  Counseling on lifestyle modifications should advise against the use of hepatotoxic medications including those sold over the counter, and cessation of smoking.

Protective measures may help limit spread of the virus to others such as hepatitis B vaccination for household contacts and safe sexual practices.  Hepatitis A vaccination should be administered and screening for other blood-borne infectious diseases should be performed.

Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ MRI of the liver and initiation of tenofovir:
Incorrect: Screening for hepatocellular carcinoma in patients with chronic hepatitis B is necessary and is typically done with ultrasound.  MRI can be used for further evaluation of concerning findings, or if the ultrasound is inconclusive.  
❌ CT scan of the liver and initiation of lamivudine:
Incorrect:  Screening for hepatocellular carcinoma in patients with chronic hepatitis B is necessary and typically done with ultrasound.  CT scan can be used for further evaluation of concerning findings,, or if the ultrasound is inconclusive and the patient has a contraindication to having an MRI.  
❌ Ultrasound of the liver and referral for liver transplant:
Incorrect:  Ultrasound of the liver is indicated for hepatocellular carcinoma screening in patients with chronic hepatitis B, however, liver transplant is not indicated at this time in this stable patient without signs of fulminant hepatic failure.  
❌ Ultrasound of the liver and serial monitoring of labs:
Incorrect: Ultrasound of the liver is indicated for hepatocellular carcinoma screening in patients with chronic hepatitis B; however this patient also requires initiation of antiviral medication given his family history, age, laboratory findings, and plans for use of immunosuppressive medications.
